prompts: An X-ray of a giant cell tumor, a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor.
A lytic, eccentric lesion in the epiphysis of a long bone, extending to the articular surface.
Radiograph showing a geographic bone lesion with a well-defined, non-sclerotic border.
A medical scan presenting a 'soap bubble' appearance, characteristic of a giant cell tumor.
An X-ray showing multiple osteochondromas, a condition known as hereditary multiple exostoses.
Multiple bony projections with cartilage caps, typically seen in a young patient.
Radiograph showing multiple exostoses pointing away from the nearest joint, causing bone deformity.
An X-ray of an osteochondroma, the most common benign bone tumor.
A cartilage-capped bony projection on the external surface of a bone.
This radiograph shows a pedunculated or sessile lesion with cortical and medullary continuity with the host bone.
An X-ray of an osteofibrous dysplasia, a benign fibro-osseous lesion.
A well-circumscribed, intracortical, lytic lesion, typically in the tibia.
Radiograph showing a hazy, ground-glass appearance within the bone lesion.
An X-ray of a benign bone tumor, not otherwise specified.
A non-aggressive bone lesion with well-defined borders and a sclerotic rim.
A focal benign process within the bone, showing no signs of aggressive features.
An X-ray of a simple or unicameral bone cyst.
A centrally located, well-defined lytic lesion in the metaphysis of a long bone.
This scan shows a fluid-filled cavity with a thin sclerotic rim and may show a 'fallen fragment' sign after a fracture.
An X-ray of synovial osteochondromatosis, a benign condition of the joint lining.
Multiple small, calcified or ossified loose bodies within a joint or bursa.
Radiograph showing multiple intra-articular nodules of similar size, causing a 'bag of marbles' appearance.
An X-ray of osteosarcoma, a highly malignant bone tumor that produces bone.
An aggressive, poorly defined lesion in the metaphysis of a long bone, often around the knee.
Radiograph showing a 'sunburst' or 'sun-ray' periosteal reaction and extensive bone destruction.
This scan presents a finding of Codman's triangle and production of tumor osteoid, classic for osteosarcoma.
An X-ray of a malignant bone tumor, not otherwise specified.
An aggressive bone lesion with ill-defined borders, cortical destruction, and a soft tissue mass.
A focal malignant process within the bone, suspicious for a primary sarcoma or a metastatic lesion.
A normal X-ray with no significant findings or abnormalities.
This radiograph shows a healthy bone and joint structure with intact cortex and normal density.
No evidence of fracture, dislocation, degenerative changes, or tumor.
An X-ray showing disc space narrowing, a sign of degenerative disc disease.
Decreased height of the intervertebral disc space in the spine.
This radiograph shows that the space between two vertebrae is reduced.
An X-ray showing foraminal stenosis, a type of degenerative condition.
Narrowing of the neural foramen where spinal nerves exit.
Radiograph showing encroachment on a nerve root canal.
An X-ray showing osteophytes, also known as bone spurs.
Bony projections that form along joint margins.
Li-pping of the vertebral endplates on a spinal radiograph.
An X-ray showing spondylolisthesis.
Anterior displacement or slippage of a vertebra over the one below it.
This scan shows a misalignment of the spinal column.
An X-ray showing a miscellaneous or other type of lesion.
An unspecified focal abnormality in the bone.
A radiographic finding that does not fit into a clear category.
An X-ray showing a surgical implant.
Presence of a high-density metallic device, such as a screw, plate, or rod.
This radiograph shows a joint replacement or arthroplasty.
An X-ray of a vertebral collapse or compression fracture.
A loss of height in the vertebral body, often resulting in a wedge shape.
This scan shows a compression deformity of a vertebra.
An X-ray of a bone fracture, a type of trauma.
A clear fracture line showing a discontinuity in the bone cortex.
This medical scan presents a finding of displaced bone fragments.
A benign or non-aggressive lesion.
A well-defined lesion with a narrow zone of transition.
A radiograph showing a benign process.
A malignant or aggressive lesion.
An ill-defined lesion with cortical destruction.
A radiograph showing a malignant process.
An X-ray image showing a type of bone tumor.
A radiograph with signs of a bone neoplasm.
A focal lesion altering the normal bone architecture.
An X-ray image showing a type of degenerative disease.
A radiograph with signs of joint wear and tear.
Age-related changes affecting the joints or spine.
A miscellaneous or normal radiographic finding.
An X-ray that is not a tumor, trauma, or degenerative disease.
An incidental or non-specific radiographic finding.
An X-ray image showing a type of trauma.
A radiograph with signs of an acute injury.
Evidence of a fracture or dislocation.
This finding is located in the hand.
A lesion appearing on a bone within the hand.
An abnormality seen in the region of the hand.
A finding present in the carpal, metacarpal, or phalangeal bones of the hand.
This finding is located in the ulna bone.
A lesion appearing on the ulna, one of the two forearm bones.
An abnormality seen in the ulnar region of the forearm.
A finding present on the ulna.
This finding is located in the radius bone.
A lesion appearing on the radius, the other forearm bone.
An abnormality seen in the radial region of the forearm.
A finding present on the radius.
This finding is located in the humerus, the bone of the upper arm.
A lesion appearing on the humeral shaft, head, or neck.
An abnormality seen in the region of the humerus.
A finding present on the humerus bone.
This finding is located in the foot.
A lesion appearing on a bone of the foot, such as a tarsal or metatarsal.
An abnormality seen in the region of the foot.
A finding present in the bones of the foot.
This finding is located in the tibia, also known as the shin bone.
A lesion appearing on the tibial plateau or shaft.
An abnormality seen in the tibial region of the lower leg.
A finding present on the tibia.
This finding is located in the fibula, the smaller bone of the lower leg.
A lesion appearing on the fibula bone.
An abnormality seen in the fibular region, alongside the tibia.
A finding present on the fibula.
This finding is located in the femur, also known as the thigh bone.
A lesion appearing on the femoral head, neck, or shaft.
An abnormality seen in the region of the femur, the longest bone in the body.
A finding present on the femur bone.
This finding is located in the pelvis.
A lesion appearing on a bone of the pelvic girdle, such as the ilium or ischium.
An abnormality seen in the pelvic region.
A finding present on a pelvic bone.
This finding is in an unspecified or unknown body part.
The location of this finding is not determined.
An abnormality seen in an unknown anatomical region.
